article:
Barditch High School decided to have an All-School Reunion.Over 450 people came to the  _  .There were tours of the old school building and a picnic at Confederate Park.Several former teachers were on hand to tell stories about the  _  days.Ms.Mabel Yates, the English teacher for over fifty years, was  _  to
the Park.
Some eyes rolled and there were a few low groans   _  Ms.Yates was about to speak.Many started looking at their watches and  coming up  with excuses to be anywhere instead of preparing to listen to a
lecture  _  an old woman who had few kind words for her
students and made them work harder than all the other teachers  _  .
Then Ms.Yates started to speak : "I can't tell you how  _  I am to be here.I haven't seen many of you since your graduation, but I have  _  your
careers and enjoyed your victories as well as cried for your tragedies.I have a large  _  of newspaper photographs of my students.  _   I haven't appeared in person, I have attended your college graduations, weddings and even the births of your children, in my imagination."
         Ms.Yates paused and started crying a bit.Then she continued:
         "It was my  _  that if I pushed you as  _  as I
could, some of you would succeed to please me and others would succeed to annoy
me.Regardless of our motives, I can see that you have all been successful in your  _  path."
"There is no greater comfort for an educator than to see the end result of his or her years of work.You have all been a great   _  of pleasure and pride for  _  and I want you to know I love you all from the bottom of my heart."
         There was a silence over the crowd for a few seconds and then  _  started
clapping.The clapping turned into cheering, then into a   _  roar  .Lawyers, truck drivers, bankers and models were rubbing their eyes or crying  _  with no shame all because of
the words from a long forgotten  _  teacher from their
hometown.
